qas.question: What did samurai mean nearly the same thing as?
How much of Japan were samurais?
Where do samurais' teachings live on?

answers.text: everyday life and in modern Japanese martial arts
middle and upper echelons of the warrior class

context: By the end of the 12th century, samurai became almost entirely synonymous with <a0_0>bushi<a0_0/>, and the word was closely associated with the <a4_0>middle and upper echelons of the warrior class<a4_0/>. The samurai were usually associated with <a1_0>a clan<a1_0/> and their lord, were trained as officers in military tactics and grand strategy, and they followed a set of rules that later came to be known as the bushidō. While the samurai numbered <a2_0>less than 10%<a2_0/> of then Japan's population, their teachings can still be found today in both <a3_0>everyday life and in modern Japanese martial arts<a3_0/>.
